numbered_ace_sentences: 1. The graph shows a relationship between elite colleges and the selection of applicants based on economic status and family legacy.
2. The black line represents legacy applicants.
3. The gray line represents non-legacy applicants.
4. The black line is significantly higher than the gray line.
5. This indicates that elite colleges favor legacy applicants.
6. A legacy applicant appears to have about double the chance of acceptance.
7. A parent has an income percentile.
8. Both types of applicants have a spiked chance of acceptance when the parent's income surpasses the 90th percentile.
9. Some applicants without legacy status are middle-class applicants.
10. A middle-class applicant without legacy status has a lower chance of acceptance than a poorer applicant without legacy status.
11. A middle-class applicant without legacy status has a lower chance of acceptance than a richer applicant without legacy status.
12. Some colleges may discriminate against middle-class applicants.
13. A middle-class applicant is not rich enough to generate a lot of money for a college.
14. A middle-class applicant is not poor enough to improve a college's statistics about financial diversity.
15. I am a current senior.
16. I apply to college.
17. I have witnessed some students get into colleges because of legacy status.
18. I have witnessed some students get into colleges because their parents have a higher income.
19. Two applicants can have the same statistics.
20. Even if two applicants have the same statistics, a college will choose the legacy applicant.
21. Even if two applicants have the same statistics, a college will choose the richer applicant.
22. This situation has hurt many students.
23. This situation has hurt me.
24. A middle-class applicant without legacy status has a disadvantage when applying to elite colleges.
25. The headline is: College: The Legacy of a Rich Man’s World!
